tit.cmt: タイトルのため、括弧内の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 日本刺繍（にほんししゅう）とは絹糸を両手を使って刺していく刺繍のことをいう。
sen.e: "Nihon shishu" is the Japanese handiwork embroidery, in which the silk thread is used.
"Nihon shishu" is Japanese handmade embroidery made using silk thread.
"Nihon shishu" is Japanese handmade embroidery made using silk thread.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 主に和服や帯、相撲の化粧廻し、日本人形に用いられている。
sen.e: Nihon shishu is seen mainly in Japanese traditional clothes, these clothes' sashes, "kesho-mawashi" (the ornamental apron) seen in "sumo" (the Japanese-style wrestling), and the Japanese doll.
Nihon shishu is seen mainly in Japanese traditional clothes and sashes, "kesho-mawashi" (the ornamental apron) seen in "sumo" (Japanese-style wrestling), and Japanese dolls.
Nihon shishu is seen mainly in Japanese traditional clothes and sashes, kesho-mawashi (the ornamental apron) seen in sumo (Japanese-style wrestling), and Japanese dolls.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 古くは甲冑などに施されている。
sen.e: In old days, it was seen in armor, helmet and others.
In ancient times, it was used on armor, helmets and the like.
In ancient times, it was used on armor, helmets and the like.

sen.j: 日本刺繍は生産地によって呼び名が変わり、京都では京繍、江戸（東京）では江戸刺繍、加賀（金沢市）では加賀刺繍と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The name of nihon shishu varies from place to place, so the embroidery produced in Kyoto is called "Kyoshu" (Kyoto Embroidery), that in "Edo" (the present Tokyo) is called "Edo shishu" (Edo Embroidery), and that in "Kaga" (the present Kanazawa City) is caled "Kaga shishu" (Kaga Embroidery).

The name of nihon shishu varies from place to place, so the embroidery produced in Kyoto is called "Kyoshu" (Kyoto Embroidery), in "Edo" (the present Tokyo) it is called "Edo shishu" (Edo Embroidery), and in "Kaga" (the present Kanazawa City) it is called "Kaga shishu" (Kaga Embroidery).

The name of nihon shishu varies from place to place, so the embroidery produced in Kyoto is called Kyoshu (Kyoto Embroidery), in Edo (the present Tokyo) it is called Edo shishu (Edo Embroidery), and in Kaga (the present Kanazawa City) it is called Kaga shishu (Kaga Embroidery).
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: また、「伝統的工芸品産業の振興に関する法律」では経済産業省が認定する伝統工芸は国から指定によって保護や援助を受けているが、日本刺繍の中では「京繍」のみが指定されている。
sen.e: The Law for the Promotion of Traditional Craft Industries prescribes that the traditional crafts designated by Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry are granted the governmental protection and aid, and of nihon shishu, only Kyoshu is designated as such.
sen.cmt: ・法律名の英訳については以下のホームページを参照しています。[http://www.kougei.or.jp/english/promotion.html]
sen.e: The Law for the Promotion of Traditional Craft Industries states that the traditional crafts designated by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry are granted governmental protection and aid, however, of all nihon shishu, only Kyoshu is designated as such.

The 'Law for the Promotion of Traditional Craft Industries' states that the traditional crafts designated by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry are granted governmental protection and aid, however, of all nihon shishu, only Kyoshu is designated as such.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 現在、市販されている着物や帯に施されているもののほとんどは機械刺繍であり、手作業による日本刺繍はとても貴重で珍しい。
sen.e: At present, Japanese traditional clothes and these clothes' sashes sold on the market are mostly embroidered mechanically, so nihon shishu, the handiwork embroidery, is quite precious and rare.
At present, Japanese traditional clothes and sashes sold on the market are mostly embroidered mechanically, so nihon shishu, being embroidered by hand, is quite precious and rare.
At present, Japanese traditional clothes and sashes sold on the market are mostly embroidered mechanically, so nihon shishu, being embroidered by hand, is quite precious and rare.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 日本刺繍の原点は約西暦500年にインドから中国のシルクロードを渡って伝えられた「繍仏」にある。
sen.e: Nihon shishu originated from "shubutsu" (embroidered Buddha), which came from India via the Silk Road in China around A.D. 500.
Nihon shishu originated from "shubutsu" (embroidered Buddha), which came from India via the Silk Road in China around A.D. 500.
Nihon shishu originated from 'shubutsu' (embroidered Buddha), which came from India via the Silk Road in China around A.D. 500.

sen.j: 繍仏とは仏像を刺繍によって表現する技法である。
sen.e: Shubutsu is the technique of portraying the Buddhist image with the embroidery.
Shubutsu is the technique of portraying the image of Buddha with embroidery.
Shubutsu is the technique of portraying the image of Buddha with embroidery.

sen.j: 日本で特に繍仏が広まったのは寺や仏像が盛んに作られた推古天皇の時代であり、日本でも繍仏の製作が広く行われるようになった。
sen.e: The production of shubutsu spread in Japan under the reign of Empress Suiko, when temples and Buddha statues were actively constructed.
sen.cmt: ・セル17の「仏像」は「仏様の肖像画」の意味であり、ここの「仏像」は「仏様の彫像」の意味なので、それぞれ別の訳を充てています。
sen.e: The production of shubutsu spread in Japan under the reign of Empress Suiko, during this time temples and statues of Buddha were actively constructed.
The production of shubutsu spread in Japan under the reign of Empress Suiko, in which temples and statues of Buddha were actively constructed.
sen.cmt: 翻訳を一部変更しました。

sen.j: 日本で現存している最古の繍仏としては「天寿国曼荼羅繍帳」があげられ、今でも奈良県の中宮寺に保管されている。
sen.e: The oldest shubutsu still existent today is "Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho" (the embroidery made in prayer for Prince Shotoku to go to Heaven after his death), which is kept in Chugu-ji Temple in Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: ・「天寿国曼陀羅繍帳」については以下のホームページを参考の上、「聖徳太子の死後、その極楽往生を祈って作成された刺繍」と解説しています。[http://www.tnm.go.jp/en/servlet/Con?pageId=B01&processId=01&event_id=2562]
sen.e: The oldest shubutsu still in existence today is "Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho" (the embroidery made in prayer for Prince Shotoku to go to Heaven after his death), which is kept in Chugu-ji Temple in Nara Prefecture.

The oldest shubutsu still in existence today is 'Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho' (the embroidery made in prayer for Prince Shotoku to go to Heaven after his death), which is kept in Chugu-ji Temple in Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 文献上で最初に登場する繍仏は西暦605年日本書紀に「飛鳥寺に安置する銅・繍の丈六の仏像をそれぞれ造らせる」と記載がある。
sen.e: "Chronicles of Japan" says in its article of A.D. 605 that a bronze Buddha statue and an embroidered Buddhist image - both about 4.8 meters, due to be placed in Asuka-dera Temple - were made, and this was the first appearance of shubutsu on historical documents.

The first appearance of shubutsu in historical documents is in the "Chronicles of Japan" where it's recorded that in A.D. 605 a bronze Buddha statue and an embroidered image of Buddha - both about 4.8 meters in size, due to be placed in Asuka-dera Temple - were made.

The first appearance of shubutsu in historical documents is in the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), where it's recorded that in A.D. 605 'a bronze Buddha statue and an embroidered image of Buddha - both about 4.8 meters in size, due to be placed in Asuka-dera Temple - were made.'
sen.cmt: 日本書紀 を追加しました。シングルクォーテーションを追加しました。

sen.j: 平安時代には貴族や富豪に豪侈品・雅楽の衣装として、安土桃山時代には能装束として用いられ、江戸時代には町人階級に普及した。
sen.e: In the Heian period, the work of nihon shishu was treasured by court nobles (or by millionaires) as a luxury or as a costume for "gagaku" (ancient Japanese court dance and music), and in the Azuchi-Momoyama period, it was used as a Noh costume, and in the Edo period, it spread among the class of the merchant.

In the Heian period, nihon shishu was treasured by court nobles and millionaires as a luxury item or as a costume for "gagaku" (ancient Japanese court dance and music), in the Azuchi-Momoyama period, it was used as costumes for Noh performers, and in the Edo period, it gained popularity among the merchant class.

In the Heian period, nihon shishu was treasured by court nobles and millionaires as a luxury item or as a costume for gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music), in the Azuchi-Momoyama period, it was used as costumes for Noh performers, and in the Edo period, it gained popularity among the merchant class.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 用具
sen.e: Tools
Tools
Tools

sen.j: 糸
sen.e: Thread
Thread
Thread

sen.j: 日本刺繍で使われる絹糸は釜糸と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The silk threads used in nihon shishu are called "kamaito" (filoselle).
The silk threads used in nihon shishu are called "kamaito" (filoselle).
The silk threads used in nihon shishu are called kamaito (filoselle).
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: これは4〜12本の細い絹糸の束で、撚りがかかっていない。
sen.e: This "kamaito" is a bunch of silk threads (from four to twelve), and they themselves are not twisted yet.
This "kamaito" is a bundle of silk threads (from four to twelve), that are not twisted yet.
This kamaito is a bundle of silk threads (from four to twelve), that are not twisted yet.
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 通常は釜糸複数本に撚り（＝ねじり）をかけて使うが、デザインによっては釜糸のまま用いることもある。
sen.e: Generally, several kamaito are put together and twisted for embroidery, but occasionally, kamaito is used as it is.
Generally, several kamaito are put together and twisted for embroidery, but occasionally, kamaito is used as it is.
Generally, several kamaito are put together and twisted for embroidery, but occasionally, kamaito is used as it is.

sen.j: 撚りをかけることにより絹糸の本来持つ光沢を生かし、縒りの強弱によって光の反射を加減し繊細な模様を表現していく。
sen.e: The twist can set off the natural luster of the silk thread, so an embroiderer adjusts the way of the light reflection by varying the strength of the twist, thereby creating the delicate design.
The twist can affect the natural luster of the silk thread, so an embroiderer adjusts the light reflection by varying the strength of the twist, thereby creating the delicate designs.
The twist can affect the natural luster of the silk thread, so an embroiderer adjusts the light reflection by varying the strength of the twist, thereby creating the delicate designs.

sen.j: また、複数の色を組み合わせることで微細な色合いを表現することが出来る。
sen.e: And a combination of several color threads can create a delicate shade of the embroidery.
Also, a combination of several colored threads can create subtle shades within the embroidery.
Also, a combination of several colored threads can create subtle shades within the embroidery.

sen.j: 針
sen.e: Needle
Needle
Needle

sen.j: 糸を通す穴の部分が平たく、針先が鋭いのが特徴。
sen.e: The characteristics of the needle used in nihon shishu are the flat eye and the sharp point.
Characteristically the needle used in nihon shishu has a flat eye and a sharp point.
Characteristically the needle used in nihon shishu has a flat eye and a sharp point.

sen.j: 近代以降は手打ちと機械打ちのものが存在している。
sen.e: In and after the modern age, the needlework has been done by machine for some, while it has been done by hand for others.
During modern times, needlework done by both machine and by hand exists.
Since modern times, needles for both machine and hand have existed.
sen.cmt: 手打ちと機械打ち用の針、と解釈して、左記のようにしました。

sen.j: 名称は太いものから順に、大太・中太・相中・相細・天細・切付・大太である。
sen.e: The names of the needles are, from the thicker one, "obuto" (ultra thick), "chubuto" (thick), "aichu" (middle), "aiboso" (thin), "tenboso" (very thin), and "kiritsuke" (ultra thin).
sen.cmt: ・最後の「大太」は誤植と判断しました。
sen.e: The names of the needles are, from thickest to thinnest, "obuto" (ultra thick), "chubuto" (thick), "aichu" (middle), "aiboso" (thin), "tenboso" (very thin), and "kiritsuke" (ultra thin).
The names of the needles are, from thickest to thinnest, obuto (ultra thick), chubuto (thick), aichu (middle), aiboso (thin), tenboso (very thin), and kiritsuke (ultra thin).
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 刺繍台
sen.e: Embroidery stand
Embroidery stand
Embroidery stand

sen.j: 反物を張るための、専用の木製の台を用いる。
sen.e: A special wooden stand is used for stretching the cloth.
A special wooden stand is used for stretching the cloth.
A special wooden stand is used for stretching the cloth.

sen.j: 左右の辺を挟んだ後、上下の辺を糸で縫い止めて、布地を固定する。
sen.e: The cloth is stretched out evenly in its left and right sides, and then threads are attached on its up and down side for fixing it.
sen.cmt: ・内容につき、下記ホームページを参照しています。[http://www.kougei.or.jp/english/crafts/0303/f0303.html] （の Stage Four）
sen.e: The cloth is stretched out evenly on its left and right sides, and then threads are attached to its top and bottom to fix it in place.
The cloth is stretched out evenly on its left and right sides, and then threads are attached to its top and bottom to fix it in place.

sen.j: 近年では、小さいものであればフランス刺繍等に用いる木枠をテーブルに固定して行なうこともある。
sen.e: Recently, a wooden square frame (for French embroidery and others) has sometimes been used for small motifs, fixed to a table.
Recently, a wooden square frame fixed to a table (for French embroidery and others), has sometimes been used for small motifs.
Recently, a wooden square frame fixed to a table (for French embroidery and others), has sometimes been used for small motifs.

sen.j: 技法
sen.e: Embroidery techniques
sen.cmt: ・各技法の名称につき、同上です（ページの下の方）。

Embroidery techniques

"Nuikiri" (Outline satin stitch)
